turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I'm sorry, gentlemen. The other day I heard such a funny story...  It still makes me laugh. It is very funny.  I am sorry. Oh yes... about this injunction...

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: The hearing is set for the twentieth of this month.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: That's two weeks from Thursday...

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: We did our utmost to have it set ahead.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I know, gentlemen, but it is in the hands of the Court. We're helpless, aren't we?

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Yes. It is unfortunate.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Well, there's nothing we can do about it. Why get excited?

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: We'll leave these papers here for your further consideration. Au revoir, madame.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Au revoir.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Give me another double brandy.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: That kind of propaganda is bad anywhere, but inciting the attendants of a powder room to go on strike.... Well, if she succeeds the consequences will be disastrous.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What can I do about it?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: She has been asked to leave the powder room but without success. We would appreciate if you would see to it yourself.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You want me to go in there?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: I'm sorry, sir, but I must insist.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Pardon me, I am very interested in what you just said -- you mean when an envoy goes back to Russia -- if they don't like what he has done they put him out of the way?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Not always... look at me... I've been back twice.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Here's my passport.... Please give me a visa. I have to leave for Russia immediately.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Count Leon d'Algout... a count!... a nobleman!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Don't hold that against me... please!

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Why should an aristocrat want to go to Russia?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Business.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: What business?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Private.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: There is no privacy in Russia. This whole thing seems very suspicious. What's the real reason? If you ever want to get into Russia, take my advice... confess!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Confess what?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Are you sympathetic to the former Czaristic government -- the White Russians?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: On the contrary -- I don't want to have anything to do with them.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: You believe in our cause?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: She must have her little joke.  You're not going to take that seriously.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: The Grand Duchess Swana... active in the White Russian movement?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Believe me, I have no connection with her any longer... I swear I haven't!

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: But you had!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Listen, I want to be absolutely frank with you. I have no business in Moscow.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: I think so too.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I want to see a friend of mine... a very dear friend.... It's a personal matter which has nothing to do with politics or social philosophies.... It's a girl.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: So it's love which drags you to Moscow.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: No visa.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I must get into that country of yours!

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Oh no. No visa.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: That's impossible! Nobody has the right.... You can't do that!... If you don't give me that visa...

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: You're going to force us... huh?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Now look here... you advertise all over the world that you want people to go into your country and when someone tries to get in, you keep him out!

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Why should I take a chance?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: On what?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: How do I know you don't want to blow up a factory?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What for... why?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Or a tunnel or a bridge...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Suspicions... nothing but suspicions!... That's the trouble with you! If you don't let me in I'll stand in front of this office of yours and warn people to keep away from Russia!... I'll picket your whole country....

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You, please.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Yes. Could you give me some information?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Gladly.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: How long do we have to wait here?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well -- until the policeman whistles again.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: At what intervals does he whistle?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: How many minutes between the first and second whistle?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: That's funny. It's interesting. I never gave it a thought before.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Have you never been caught in a similar situation?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Have I? Do you know when I come to think about it it's staggering. If I add it all up I must have spent years waiting for signals. Imagine! An important part of my life wasted between whistles.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: In other words you don't know.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You're welcome.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Can I help you?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You might hold this for me.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Love to.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Correct me if I am wrong... We are facing north, aren't we?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Facing north... I'd hate to commit myself without my compass... Pardon me... are you an explorer?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No... I am looking for the Eiffel Tower.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Is that thing lost again?... Listen... if you are interested in a view...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I am interested in the Eiffel Tower from a technical standpoint.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Technical... I couldn't help you from that angle. You see, a real Parisian only goes to the top of the tower in moments of despair to jump off.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: How long does it take a man to land?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Now, isn't that too bad! The last time I jumped I forgot to clock it!  Let me see... Eiffel Tower... Your finger, please.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Why do you need my finger?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Bad manners to point with your own... Here... the Eiffel Tower.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: And where are we?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Here... here we are... here you are and here I am... feel it?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I am interested only in the shortest distance between these two points. Must you flirt?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I don't have to but I find it natural.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Suppress it.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I'll try.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: For my own information would you call your approach toward me typical of the local morale?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Madame, it is that kind of approach which has made Paris what it is.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You are very sure of yourself, aren't you?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Nothing has occurred recently to shake my confidence.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I have heard of the arrogant male in capitalistic society. It is having a superior earning power that makes you like that.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: A Russian! I love Russians! Comrade... I have been fascinated by your Five- Year Plan for the past fifteen years!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Your type will soon be extinct.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: The foundation is one hundred and forty-one yards square...  I hope you'll forgive me but I thought you'd...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Four massive piers of masonry are sunk to a depth of forty-six feet on the side of the Seine, and twenty- nine and one-half feet on the other side. The girders of interlaced iron- work which stay the structure have an inclination of fifty-four degrees...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: That's a strange angle.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes, very strange.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You gave me some very valuable information. Thank you.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: And thank you for getting me up here. I've never seen this before. Beautiful, isn't it?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Yes, it is.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I'm glad I saw it before becoming extinct.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Do not misunderstand me. I do not hold your frivolity against you.  As basic material you might not be bad, but you are the unfortunate product of a doomed culture. I feel sorry for you.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You must admit that this doomed old civilization sparkles... It glitters!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I do not deny its beauty, but it is a waste of electricity.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What a city! There are the Grands Boulevards... blasted out of the heart of the old streets. The Arc de Triomphe... made to greet Napoleon's army. The Opera! And Montmartre... Montparnasse... La Boh√®me... and now I'll show you the greatest attraction!  It will cost me a franc but it is worth it.  The most wonderful spot in all Paris -- unique! Here, look....  What do you see?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I see a house that looks like any other house. What's remarkable about it?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: It's not the structure but the spirit which dwells within. There are three rooms and a kitchenette dedicated to hospitality.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: So that is your house?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well, let's say I live in it. Such a pleasant place... all kinds of comfort, easy to reach, close to street car, bus, and subway...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Does that mean that you want me to go there?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Please don't misunderstand me...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Then you don't want me to go there.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Now I didn't say that either... naturally nothing would please me more.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Then why don't we go?  You might be an interesting subject of study.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I will do my best.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Is this what you call the "butler"?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Good evening, comrade.  This man is horribly old. You should not make him work.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: He takes good care of that.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: He looks sad. Do you whip him?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No, though the mere thought makes my mouth water.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: The day will come when you will be free. Go to bed, little father. We want to be alone.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well, may I offer you a drink, or how about something to eat?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Thank you. I've had all the calories necessary for today.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: What do we do now?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: We take off our hat and coat.  We sit down -- we make ourselves comfortable. We adjust ourselves to the prospect of a most enjoyable evening. We look at each other. We smile.  Well... we don't smile. How about some music?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Is that customary?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: It helps. It has ever since King David wooed Bathsheba with the harp. As I am not so fortunate as to have my harp at hand, I shall turn on the radio.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I should say this room is eighteen by twenty-five.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Not too big and not too small. What I'd call the typical room of an average man. Or shall we say a little above average. Now if there are any special aspects you wish to study I have nothing to conceal. Just look around. That's my desk. Those are my books, and here am I. Where shall we begin?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I will start with you.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: That's great. I'm thirty-five years old. Just over six feet tall. I weigh a hundred and eighty-two pounds stripped.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: And what is your profession?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Keeping my body fit, keeping my mind alert, keeping my landlord appeased. That's a full-time job.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: And what do you do for mankind?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: For mankind not a thing -- for womankind the record is not quite so bleak.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You are something we do not have in Russia.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Thank you. Thank you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: That is why I believe in the future of my country.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I begin to believe in it myself since I've met you. I still don't know what to make of it. It confuses me, it frightens me a little, but it fascinates me, Ninotchka.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You pronounce it incorrectly. Ni- notchka.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Ni-notchka.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: That is correct.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Ninotchka, do you like me just a little bit?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Your general appearance is not distasteful.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Look at me. The whites of your eyes are clear. Your cornea is excellent.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Your cornea is terrific. Tell me -- you're so expert on things -- can it be that I'm falling in love with you?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You are bringing in wrong values. Love is a romantic designation for a most ordinary biological, or shall we say chemical, process. A lot of nonsense is talked and written about it.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Oh, I see. What do you use instead?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I acknowledge the existence of a natural impulse common to all.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What can I possibly do to encourage such an impulse in you?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You don't have to do a thing. Chemically we are already quite sympathetic.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You're the most improbable creature I've ever met in my life, Ninotchka, Ninotchka...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You repeat yourself.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I'd like to say it a thousand times.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Don't do it, please.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I'm at a loss, Ninotchka. You must forgive me if I appear a little old- fashioned. After all, I'm just a poor bourgeois.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: It's never too late to change. I used to belong to the petty bourgeoisie myself. My father and mother wanted me to stay and work on the farm, but I preferred the bayonet.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: The bayonet? Did you really?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I was wounded before Warsaw.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Wounded? How?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I was a sergeant in the Third Cavalry Brigade. Would you like to see my wound?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I'd love to.  Tsk, tsk, tsk.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: A Polish lancer. I was sixteen.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Poor Ninotchka. Poor, poor Ninotchka.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Don't pity me. Pity the Polish lancer. After all, I'm alive.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What kind of a girl are you, anyway?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Just what you see. A tiny cog in the great wheel of evolution.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You're the most adorable cog I ever saw in my life. Ninotchka, Cogitska, let me confess something. Never did I dream I could feel like this toward a sergeant.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Do you hear that?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: It's twelve o'clock.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: It's midnight. One half of Paris is making love to the other half. Look at the clock. One hand has met the other hand. They kiss. Isn't that wonderful?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: That's the way a clock works. There's nothing wonderful about it. You merely feel you must put yourself in a romantic mood to add to your exhilaration.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I can't possibly think of a better reason.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: It's false sentimentality.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You analyze everything out of existence. You analyze me out of existence. I won't let you. Love is not so simple. Ninotchka, Ninotchka, why do doves bill and coo? Why do snails, coldest of all creatures, circle interminably around each other? Why do moths fly hundreds of miles to find their mates? Why do flowers open their petals? Oh, Ninotchka, Ninotchka, surely you feel some slight symptom of the divine passion... a general warmth in the palms of your hands... a strange heaviness in your limbs... a burning of the lips that is not thirst but a thousand times more tantalizing, more exalting, than thirst?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Was that talkative?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No, that was restful. Again.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Oh, my barbaric Ninotchka. My impossible, unromantic, statistical...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Glorious, analytical...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: The telephone is ringing.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Oh, let it ring.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: But one of your friends may be in need of you. You must answer.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I must go.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Ninotchka, or shall I say Special Envoy Yakushova...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Let's forget that we ever met.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I have a better suggestion. Let's forget that the telephone ever rang. I never heard that you are Yakushova... you are Ninotchka... my Ninotchka...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I was sent here by my country to fight you.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: All right, fight me, fight me as much as you want, but fight me tomorrow morning! There's nothing sweeter than sharing a secret with a bitter enemy.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: As a representative of Moscow...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Tonight let's not represent anybody but ourselves.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: It is out of the question. If you wish to approach me...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You know I want to...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Then do it through my lawyer!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Ninotchka, you can't walk out like this... I'm crazy about you, and I thought I'd made an impression on you. You liked the white of my eye.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: But, Ninotchka, I held you in my arms. You kissed me!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I kissed the Polish lancer too... before he died.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Room service speaking.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Send me a plate of raw carrots and beets, beets predominating on a ratio of sixty-forty... What? There is a strike in the kitchen? Good! Will you assure the strikers of my hearty sympathy in their cause. I hope they will not weaken in their demands and tell them to put no dressing whatsoever on my vegetables... What? You won't serve me either? Now look here, Comrade, I think it is a fine idea to let the capitalists go without luncheon but when you keep food away from me you're weakening the people.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: So! You want to make a strike breaker out of me! I am surprised at you, Comrade! Is it too much for the workers of the world to ask you to walk around the corner for lunch? All I can say to you is take your hammer and sickle and get out of that Royal Suite!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Pardon me for addressing you but you insulted him, you know that. You hurt his feelings. It was just like telling a musician you don't like music. That good old man believes in food as you believe in Karl Marx. You can't go around hurting people, Comrade Yakushova, but maybe you can make it up to him. Do you know how?  By eating everything with relish, by drinking everything with gusto, by having a good time for the first time in your natural life!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I don't like your following me.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I didn't follow you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Then how did you get here?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I always eat here.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: This is a place for workmen.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: But my dear child, I am most at home among working men. I hate the places where you circulate -- the Hotel Clarence... This is my natural element. After all, what are any of us? Workingmen! At least, those of us who are worth our salt. Hyah?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Just an old man. His memory is getting weak.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: What are you after?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Must one always be after something?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Your tactics are useless. My name is neither Buljanoff, Iranoff, nor Kopalski.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Oh, Ninotchka, who wants to talk business. If you win the suit, fine. If we win the suit, better. You do me an injustice.  When we went to my apartment did I have the slightest idea that you had any connection with this deal?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: But you have now, and I know now that you are a man who employs business methods which in Russia would be punished by death.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Death! Death! Always so glum! What about life, Ninotchka! Do Russians never think of life? Of the moment in which we are living? The only moment we really have? Don't take it all so seriously, Ninotchka. Nothing is worth it. Please... relax... I beg you, Sergeant... smile!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Will you smile?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Just smile.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: At what?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: At anything. At the whole ludicrous spectacle of life. At people being pompous and taking themselves seriously and exaggerating their own importance. If you can't find anything else to laugh at you can laugh at you and me.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Because we are an odd couple.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Then you should go back to your table.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No, I can't leave you. I won't. Not yet. Not until I've made you laugh... at least once.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Ha! Ha! Now go back.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: That's not a laugh! I mean a laugh from the heart. Now let's see. I'm going to tell you a funny story. Just a moment... I've got it! Well, it seems there were a couple of Frenchmen who went to America...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: On which boat?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well, er... let's drop it. I don't think you would care for that one.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Probably not.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Do you like Scotch stories?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I have never heard one.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Two Scotchmen met on the street... and I don't know the name of the street and it really doesn't matter. Well, anyway, one's name was McIntosh and the other's was McGillicuddy. McIntosh says to McGillicuddy, "Hello, Mr. McGillicuddy," and McGillicuddy says to McIntosh, "Hello, Mr. McIntosh," and then McIntosh says to McGillicuddy, "How is Mrs. McGillicuddy?" and then McGillicuddy says to McIntosh, "How is Mrs. McIntosh?"...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I wish they had never met.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: So do I.  Now, here's a great one... Ha! Ha! Ha!  Well, maybe it's not so good. Let's forget it! How's this? Two men are looking at the moon. One says to the other, "Is it true that a lot of people live on the moon?" "Yes, it is," says the other, "five hundred million." "Whew!" replies the first, "they must get pretty crowded when it's half moon!" Ha! Ha! Ha!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I suppose you don't think that's funny?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: It seemed funny to me when I first heard it. Maybe the trouble isn't with the joke. Maybe it's with you!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Maybe you haven't any sense of humor. Well, I'll give you one more chance! Now listen!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Not funny, huh?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: So you don't think that's funny? It is funny! Everyone else thinks so! Maybe you didn't get it.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I'll tell you that joke again. A man comes into a restaurant. Did you get that?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: He sits down at the table and says to the waiter... Did you get that too?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well, so far it isn't funny, but wait. He says to the waiter, "Waiter! Bring me a cup of coffee." So the waiter comes back five minutes later and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we have no coffee."...  Wait a minute... wait a minute... I'm all mixed up...  A man comes in a restaurant, he sits down, he calls the waiter and he says, "Waiter! Get me a cup of coffee without cream," and five minutes later the waiter comes back and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we have no cream, can it be a glass of milk!"

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I don't look too foolish?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Foolish? If this dress were to walk down the boulevard all by itself I would follow it from one end of Paris to the other, and when I caught up with it I would say, "Just a moment, you charming little dress, I want you to meet Ninotchka... you two were meant for each other." Ninotchka feels more comfortable.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You remember this room?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I've never been here before. I wonder whom you're thinking of. Oh, I know, a girl with a map, figuring out each step, worrying about north and south. Today... now this might shock you... I went up to a taxi and said "Eight Rue du Bois"... and here I am.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You see? Life can be so simple.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: For twelve francs, seventy-five.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Twelve seventy-five from the Clarence? The son-of-a-gun made a detour!...  But he got you here.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: It's nine o'clock.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: That's when one half of Paris says to the other half, "What are your plans for this evening, madame?"

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Well, first I should like to take off my hat and jacket.  Then could we have some music?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: A wonderful idea! Radio or records?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Not radio. Let's have music that's just for ourselves.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You see I couldn't shout that.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Leon, you know the jokes you told me a few days ago? I wake up in the middle of the night and laugh at them. Now, Leon that's wrong. I know they're not funny, they're silly. They're stupid. And still... I laugh... and when I look at Buljanoff and Iranoff and Kopalski I know they are scoundrels and I should hate them -- then I realize who made them like that, and instead of sending my report to Moscow I tear it up and go down and buy a ridiculous hat... and if this keeps on... am I too talkative?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No... go on.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Leon, I want to tell you something which I thought I never would say, which I thought nobody ever should say, because I thought it didn't exist... and, Leon... I can't say it...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Leon, I would like to ask you something.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Anything, Ninotchka.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: If you don't want to answer, you needn't. But if you do, you must tell me the truth.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I promise... I swear.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Did you make any change in this room?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: When I was here before I noticed a photograph of a woman on the desk in a wide silver frame. I thought what a waste of silver. That's all that interested me then. Now I would like to know... what happened to the woman?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: She is very attractive. She has great elegance.  She's what you call a woman of the world, isn't she?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Ninotchka, I love you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I suppose she is very entertaining... It must be lots of fun to be with her, so witty, so glamorous...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Ninotchka, you're jealous.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Leon, don't ever ask me for a picture of myself... I couldn't bear the thought of being shut up in a drawer... I couldn't breathe, I couldn't stand it.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: My darling.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I wouldn't know. The closest I ever came to champagne was in a newsreel. The wife of some president was throwing it at a battleship.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: It's always good luck to launch something with champagne; a battleship... or an evening.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: It's funny to look back. I was brought up on goat's milk, I had a ration of vodka in the army, and now champagne.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: From goats to grapes. That's drinking in the right direction.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: From what I read I thought champagne was a strong drink. It's very delicate. Do people ever get drunk on this?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: There have been cases... but the headache the next morning is worth while -- if you drink it with the right toast.  To us, Ninotchka!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: How do you do?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: And General Savitzky.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Quickly, please... tell me one of your funny stories.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: A funny story?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You never finished the one about the two Scotchmen with the names.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well, there were two Scotchmen. One was named McIntosh and one was named McGillicuddy. They met on the street.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No, darling. I'll tell you another story, a much better one.  The only thing that will be over on Thursday is the lawsuit. There will be no Thursday for us. Not next week or any week. We won't let it happen. I'll tear it out of the calendar. Is that a good story?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Wonderful -- if one could believe it.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You must, darling.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: To the loveliest story I ever heard.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Oo! Darling! Something is the matter.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You just made that trip from goats to grapes a little too fast.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Oh, everything is so wonderful! It's getting farther and farther away!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What, darling?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Thursday.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes. Don't worry. Everything will be all right.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Comrades! Comrades!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Darling, darling... please!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I must talk to my brothers!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Shhh! Shhh!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Don't shush me. I am People! I want to make a speech. I want to overthrow the Duchess!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: But, darling, you can't do that.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Comrades! Good people of France!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Now, Ninotchka... please!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: They are all Duchesses here... thousands of Duchesses... and I am going to tell them.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Quite right... yes, yes, yes, but first you're going in that door and you're going to take a little spirits of ammonia and lie down.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No speech?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No speech.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I love you, my little Leonitchka!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: And I adore you, Ninotchua.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Don't tell them where we're going, sweetheart.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No. Nobody will find us.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Are we going to build our little house?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes... a little white house.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Not white, darling.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: All right, we'll make it red.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No, don't let's have it any color... no color... just a house house... let's form our own party.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Right: Lovers of the world unite!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: And we won't stretch up our arms...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No! No!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: ...and we won't clench our fist...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No! No!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Our salute will be a kiss.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes... a kiss... salute!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I am so happy. No one can be so happy without being punished. I will be punished and I should be punished.  I want to confess, darling.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I know... it's the Russian soul.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Everyone wants to confess and if they don't confess they make them confess. I am a traitor. When I kissed you I betrayed the Russian ideal. Leon, I should be stood up against the wall.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Would that make you any happier?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Much happier.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I have paid the penalty. Now let's have some music.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Let's turn on the radio.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Radio! What is radio?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: It's a little box that you buy on the installment plan and before you tune it in they tell you they have a new model.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Oh yes, yes. It has a little knob that turns... a little knob... it must be somewhere around here... yes... here... I see...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What shall we get? The news!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No, no news. We don't want to know what's happening in the world. We want to be left alone, don't we?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes, sweetheart... all by ourselves.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Well, then we turn twice to the right and stop at seven...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: It's dead.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well, it has to warm up... you have to give it a chance... just like people... like you and me... first you wanted to fight me and now we belong to the same party... salute!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No music.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No, no music.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: There it is... Thursday... you can't rip it out of the week....

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: But I can throw it out of the window.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: It wouldn't be fair to the man in the street.  There they are... they are terrible things, those jewels....

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: ...but big.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: ...they are the tears of Old Russia... see that stone?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Who cried that one?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Czar Peter gave it to his wife, Catherine the Great. For it he sold ten thousand serfs in the market.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Now, darling, don't get impatient, wait until we are married. You know that worthless butler of mine... that reactionary? Some day when I come home to you I may say, "Darling, I drove Gaston to the market and look what I got from him!"

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Come, sweetheart. Let me put it on you. You will teach these jewels. For the first time they will learn how they can look.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: They belong to the people.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I give them back to the people...  I make you Ninotchka the Great... Duchess of the People!... Grand Duchess of the People!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Is this the wish of the masses?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: It is their wish.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Thank you, Leon... thank you, masses.  Can I make a speech now?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Comrades! People of the world! The revolution is on the march... I know... wars will wash over us... bombs will fall... all civilization will crumble... but not yet, please... wait, wait... what's the hurry?  Let us be happy... give us our moment....  We are happy, aren't we, Leon?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes, sweetheart.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: So happy and so tired.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: They wouldn't let me in so I had to get you out.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: So -- you're behind all this. I should have known.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Trying to keep me away from you! It couldn't be done. Naturally I couldn't go on forever punching passport officials in the nose -- but I found a way, didn't I? Darling, I had to see you. I wrote and wrote but all my letters came back.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: The one I got they wouldn't let me read.  It began, "Ninotchka, my darling," and ended, "Yours, Leon."

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I won't tell you what came between... I'll prove it. It will take a long time, Ninotchka... at least a lifetime.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: But, Leon, I am only here for a few days.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: If you don't stay with me, I'll have to continue my fight. I'll travel wherever Russian commissions are. I'll turn them all into Buljanoffs, Iranoffs, and Kopalskis. The world will be crowded with Russian restaurants. I'll depopulate Russia. Once you saved your country by going back. This time you can save it by staying here.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Well, when it is a choice between my personal interest and the good of my country, how can I waver? No one shall say Ninotchka was a bad Russian.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Hello, Leon!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Good morning, Swana.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: It's really a wretched morning... wretched. I can't get myself right. I wanted to look mellow and I look brittle. My face doesn't compose well... all highlights... how can I dim myself down, Leon? Suggest something. I am so bored with this face. I wish I had someone else's face. Whose face would you have if you had your choice? Oh, well, I guess one gets the face one deserves.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Your conversation has one marvelous advantage, Swana. However many questions you ask you never expect an answer.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Don't you find that restful?... Why didn't you come last night?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Darling, I was busy looking out for your interests.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Did you win?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: We can forget horse racing, roulette, the stock market... our worries are over! You remember that platinum watch with the diamond numbers? You will be in a position to give it to me.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Oh, Leon, you are so good to me.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: We can be rich if you say the word. I had dinner with the Guizots last night.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Those newspaper people?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You'd be surprised how many nice people dine with the Guizots.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: What a gruesome proof of the power of the press!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Now listen, Swana... I sold Monsieur Guizot the idea of publishing your memoirs in the Gazette Parisienne. "The Life and Loves of the Grand Duchess Swana of Russia"!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Oh, Leon!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Sweetheart, we won't have to bother about our future if you are willing to raffle off your past!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Was it for this that I refused to endorse Dr. Bertrand's Mouthwash? I could have made a little fortune by saying that the Vincent Vacuum Cleaner was the only vacuum cleaner ever used by the Romanoffs... and now you want them to smear my life's secrets over the front page of a tabloid?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I understand how you feel, but there is a limit to everything, particularly pride and dignity. They are willing to pay any price! They have a circulation of two million!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Imagine two million clerks and shop girls peeking into my life for a sou! Think of my lovely life being wrapped around cheese and blood sausages! I can see a big grease spot in the midst of my most intimate moments!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: My little Volga boatman! Stop threatening! I don't deserve this.  Are you my little Volga boatman?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Now, Swana...

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: First tell me, are you my little Volga boatman?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes, I'm your little Volga boatman.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Well... two million readers... I know exactly what they want. Chapter One: "A Childhood behind Golden Bars. Lovely Little Princess Plays with Rasputin's Beard."

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I've got one chapter Guizot thinks is terrific. "Caviar and Blood." Swana escapes over the ice!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: A couple of bloodhounds and we have Uncle Tom's Cabin.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Darling, this would be wonderful! Just once... weren't you attacked by a Bolshevik?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Was I? No... not by a Bolshevik!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Too bad! Brings our price down ten thousand francs!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: He's a waiter at the Clarence, poor devil. You know him.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Tell him I won't be able to see him for a half an hour.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Did I hear something about jewels?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Rakonin, bless him, has given me the most amazing news!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: This is the Duchess Swana... I want to speak to Monsieur Cornillon... it's very important... please get him right away... Hello, Monsieur Cornillon? The most incredible thing has happened! My jewels are here in Paris! Three Bolshevik swine are trying to sell them! Yes... yes... we must act immediately!... Call the police... Have them arrested!... Well, then, get an injunction!... But do something, Monsieur Cornillon!  ...But they are my jewels! There must be some way of getting them back!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What does he say?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Shhh!  ...But how can there be a question?... Are you my lawyer or theirs?... All right, I'll let you know!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: It looks pretty hopeless... there may be a chance... that's all... The French Government has recognized Soviet Russia and he doubts that they will risk a war for my poor sake. He might be able to make up some kind of a case but it would cost money, money, money!... That's all they are interested in -- those lawyers!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Darling, calm down. Why do you need a lawyer? Haven't you your little Volga boatman?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Leon! What in heaven's name...!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Is anything wrong? Are you ill?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Don't tell me the bed has lost its best friend.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I just couldn't sleep. I got up and went back... and then got up again. These last few days... whew!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Darling, you're taking my business affairs far too seriously. Much as I'd love to rob the Bolsheviks of their filthy money, I won't do it at the expense of your health. Particularly as we know we won't get much.  You look so pale... pale but interesting.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Make it ice cold.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Not in your condition.  Make it tepid, Gaston... tepid and tender. And lay out his gray suit.  Afterwards I'll drive you through the Bois. Slowly... in Waltz time.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Now... here we have two very handsome soft-boiled eggs. Do you suppose hens mind what happens to their eggs? Probably not. They have such unfeeling eyes. We'll put in a great nugget of butter, plenty of pepper and salt... Darling, I haven't seen you for three livelong days... seventy-two hours!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Oh, please, Swana! I don't know whether I'm standing on my head or my heels. Here you are blaming me for neglecting you when I'm trying to concentrate on another woman and can't get near her.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: You haven't seen her yet?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No, and believe me I've tried everything! I must have telephoned her a hundred times. I've sent her telegrams, I've sent her flowers... I asked her to dinner... I offered her seats for the Opera...

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: That proletarian! In the old days we'd have had her flogged.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: That wouldn't have done any good. Not with her.  She's the most incredible creature I've ever seen.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: You just told me you hadn't seen her.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well... er... I caught a glimpse of her when she walked through the lobby.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Imagine the carpets of a self- respecting Parisian hotel dirtied by the boots of a muzhik! What does she look like?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You can't imagine.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: That bad?  Old or young?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Timeless. When she comes into a room you'd think that the Bolsheviks had taken over Paris. She wears her cheap miserable blouse as though it were the latest model by Schiaparelli. What a woman! What a woman! There is a Russian snowstorm in each of her eyes.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: You saw all that in one glimpse?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Darling, if we're going to get anywhere someone has to keep his eyes open!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Now, darling, soak in your beautiful pine bath and let Gaston shave you.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Is this your new dress suit?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes, Swana.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Didn't I tell you Benson and Benson were the tailors for you?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes, Swana, you did.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: It's a dream of beauty. He never takes my word for anything, but I was right, wasn't I?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes, Swana.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Am I interrupting?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Not at all. Your Highness, may I present Madame Yakushova?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: How do you do?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: I've some wonderful news for you, Leon. It's about Punchy... do you mind if I sit down?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No... please...

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: He won another blue ribbon and bit the judge. Ha! ha! ha! I bought him the cutest sweater as a reward. You should see him strut down the street in it. He looks like a little boulevardier.  You see, Count d'Algout gave me Punchy for my birthday.  You must have searched weeks before you found anything as divine as Punchy, didn't you, Leon?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Months, Swana.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Poor Madame Yakushova... here we are talking in mysteries.... I'm sure you wonder what it's all about.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: There's a charming crowd here tonight, isn't there?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: I'm going, Leon...  but before I leave I must compliment you on your gown, Madame Yakushova. Is that what they're wearing in Moscow this year?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Will you do me a favor? Stop talking about the good old days.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: A very wise suggestion, Leon. I'm afraid madame and I will never agree.  The only thing we have in common is our lawsuit and that will be decided next week. I understand everything will be over by Thursday. Am I right?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Leon, darling, how nice! Have you ordered tea or a cocktail?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No thanks, Swana.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Did I act stupidly last night? Should I apologize?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I'm the one who should apologize. I should have talked to you before.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Is this, by any chance, going to be a confession?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Oh, no, my little Volga boatman. Have you forgotten our First Commandment: Never Complain -- Never Explain. It has worked so often and so perfectly, don't let's break the rule. And please don't look so guilty, otherwise I'll...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: This time, Swana -- just this once -- I must ask you to listen.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: All right, I'll listen.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I know you hate the obvious but do you mind if, at this moment, I'm not in the least subtle?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Brutal frankness, if you insist.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: There are a hundred ways to approach it, but I feel it can best be said in one simple phrase. I'm in love, Swana.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: And I thought it was something serious! How could you frighten me so?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: It must be serious, Swana. Not long ago I'd have considered such a statement rather juvenile and rather middle class. Now I can say it without stammering, without a blush. I'm in love, Swana.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Say it over and over again, Leon. Words are a wonderful safety valve, and that's what you need -- because you know it's impossible, don't you?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I have to be simple again, Swana, and you may find it shockingly banal. I've thought it over and I'm willing to take all the consequences, even if it means a complete readjustment of my way of living.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Leon! This has the ugly sound of regeneration.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I'm afraid that's what it is.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: The same old trouble, Leon. You're always late. Whether you're taking me to the Opera or calling for me at a beauty shop, you're never on time. And now, when it's a question of your reform -- late again.  By about five minutes.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What is this, Swana?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Knowing the efficiency of the French Air Service I think I can guarantee that Madame Yakushova has already taken off for Moscow.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Has done what?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: She's gone, Leon.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Do you expect me to believe that?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Hello, Leon darling!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: After our talk last night I took it for granted that you would drop in here this morning. Knowing how difficult it is to get into Soviet Russia, I thought I might be of some assistance to you.  May I introduce myself? I am the Duchess Swana of Russia... another Russia.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Now, please, Swana.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Count d'Algout was for several years my personal representative and if it is necessary to sign any affidavit for him I'll be delighted.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: That does it, Swana.  Now you mustn't miss your appointment with your hair-dresser.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Just in case they don't give you your visa to Russia I want you to know that I have signed a contract for my memoirs and rented a lovely little ch√¢teau in the Touraine, and if you feel the need of a change...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Thank you, Swana. You are very gracious.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Not at all.... I understand perfectly, Count d'Algout gave you a dog. You made it very clear, madame.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Dear me... I must be losing my finesse. If I'm not careful I'll be understood by everybody.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Isn't it amazing! One gets a wrong impression of the new Russia.  It must be charming. I'm glad conditions are so improved. I assume this is what the factory workers wear at their dances?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Exactly. You see, it would have been embarrassing for people of my sort to wear low-cut gowns in the old Russia. The lashes of the Cossacks across our backs were not very becoming, and you know how vain women are.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: You're absolutely right about the Cossacks. We made an unpardonable mistake when we let them use their knouts. They had such reliable guns.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You're right, madame, it will all be over by Thursday.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: It is unfortunate that you have so few more days in Paris.  Be sure and redouble your efforts so that madame can take some pleasant memories when she returns to Moscow.  Good night.  Good night, Leon.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: It is tomorrow morning... tomorrow noon, to be exact. I hope you will forgive me. I know it's extremely cruel to waken anyone at such an hour. Don't you recognize me? I am the Duchess Swana.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I think we can cut your visit short. Leon is not here.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Of course not, my dear! I didn't come here with any such suspicion. How ridiculous!  Nor did I come here to pick up his hat.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: How stale last night's gaiety looks! It has the taste of a dead cigarette.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: If you were encouraged to come here by our meeting last night I am afraid you misunderstood my attitude.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Don't worry, you were quite rude enough.  Do you mind if I let in a little fresh air and sunshine? I'm sure it will make you feel better and I want you to be at your very best. In full possession of your faculties, at least.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Please come to the point. What is it you want?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: I just dropped in to have a little heart-to-heart talk with you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: We have nothing to discuss.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Now there you are completely wrong. If we sit down for a little chat, I'm sure we won't run out of conversation and what's more it won't be dull.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Madame, what is it you people always say, regardless of what you mean... "I am delighted to have you here"? I have not reached that stage of civilization.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: That's all right... I grow on people.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I must ask you to leave.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Leave? That's exactly what I came here to ask you to do. Leave! I don't mean this hotel and I don't mean Paris... I mean France. There's a plane for Moscow at five-forty.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Madame, if you...

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Don't worry. I have already made reservations. It's perfect flying weather. They assure me there's a fine tail wind which will sweep you back to Moscow in no time.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: If this is meant to be a joke it is not funny. Or do you still think you're issuing orders from your palace in Petrograd?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: My palace in Petrograd... yes, you took that away from me. You took away my czar, my country, my people, everything I had...  but nothing more -- I warn you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: People cannot be taken away, madame, neither a hundred and sixty million nor one. Not if you have their love. You hadn't. That's why you're not in Russia any longer, and that's why you came here this morning.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Very interesting, my dear, but couldn't you write all that from Moscow? A dissertation on love on Soviet stationery -- would be an amusing paradox.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: It is not enough to be witty, madame. People grow tired of being entertained. You made that mistake before. Problems were never solved by bowing from a balcony.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: My dear, you don't know how impressive I could be. Did you ever see me in my regalia with my diadem and all my jewels?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: You can't deny we gave the people their money's worth -- almost -- eight tumbling Romanoffs -- eight!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I must insist that you leave.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Not before you agree to use those reservations to Moscow.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: In that case I can only say good-by.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: I wouldn't waken Leon. After last night I would say not before three o'clock at the earliest.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I told you to go, madame.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Believe me, Leon can't help you. He doesn't know anything about the jewels... I give you my word... I swear it.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Where are they?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: You were very careless with our precious jewels, my dear. They're too expensive a toy for two children to play with.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Where are they?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Don't worry. Fortunately last night a very trustworthy friend kept his eyes open. Perhaps he overstepped his function as a waiter but he fulfilled his duty as a Russian.  I just put this on for sentiment. The rest are absolutely safe. I assure you. But if you feel like notifying the police...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You leave me no choice.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Won't it be rather embarrassing for a Soviet Envoy to disclose the circumstances under which she lost them?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I will have to face the consequences, but so will you. Don't forget they will ask how you got them.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: That's very simple to answer. They were given to me by my mother. They were given to her by her mother, in fact they're mine, you cannot steal what belongs to you!

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: They always belonged to the Russian people. They were paid for with their sweat, their blood, their lives and you will give them back!

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: I told you we had plenty to talk about. Shall we sit down?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Now, let's free ourselves from emotionalism and try to solve the problem in a practical way. Our situation has changed considerably. Before I had only a claim to the jewels. Now I have the jewels.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: In other words moral ideas have no weight with you... all right, then let's deal with legal facts. You know that France has recognized the Soviet.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Unfortunately.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Under Soviet law the jewels belong to the State. France is going to uphold that ownership.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: My lawyer agrees with you. He says France will uphold it in every court, but I will drag you through every court, don't forget that. And when I say it will take two years I am, as always, conservative.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Won't those two years in court be expensive for you? I know that money was no object as long as you could squeeze it from the pockets of the people, but now...

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: I may run out of money, but you have already run out of bread. Two years is a long time for your comrades to wait.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I see. You have calculated in terms of hunger.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: No, I just wanted to be absolutely impartial. Both of us are faced with two rather uncomfortable years. We can condense these two years to two minutes if you want to accept my proposition. Ninotchka now realizes what she is after.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: I am willing to hand over the jewels and sign the necessary papers if you take that five-forty plane to Moscow.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: That's not the way to win him back... not Leon.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: I think I know Leon quite as well as you... possibly a little better. Leave that worry to me. Five-forty leaves you time enough to close the deal with Monsieur Mercier, but naturally you'll be too busy for any farewells. I'll see to it that everything is done in the most expeditious manner and I will also see you to the airport. That's my proposition, Comrade Yakushova.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: Here, please...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: May I have your bags, madame?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: Well... that's my business, madame.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: That's no business... that's a social injustice.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: That depends on the tip.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: Good morning, Comrade.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Good morning, Comrade Commissar. Here is my report on the materials available for trading in the next four months.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: Does this include the products of the Far Eastern provinces?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Yes, it does.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: You mean you have finished the whole investigation?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: That's marvelous.... You must have worked day and night.... Don't you ever sleep?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I need very little sleep. We must be extremely careful what goods we take in exchange. I have already started a survey of our most urgent needs.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: Well, Comrade, I am afraid you will have to turn over that work to someone else.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: May I ask why?

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: Please... sit down.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: Cigarette?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: Well, Comrade, have you heard from your friends Kopalski, Buljanoff, and Iranoff?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: I haven't either, but I've heard about them. You must realize it was only on the strength of your Paris report that I sent them to Constantinople; without that I never would have trusted them on a mission as important as the fur deal.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: May I ask what has happened?

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: As soon as our representatives go to a foreign country they seem to lose all sense of balance. If I told you what's going on in Constantinople right now you wouldn't believe it. Those three have been sitting there for six weeks and haven't sold a piece of fur.  This anonymous report was sent me. They are dragging the good name of our country through every caf√© and night club. Here...  "How can the Bolshevik cause gain respect among the Moslems if your three representatives, Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski, get so drunk that they throw a carpet out of their hotel window and complain to the management that it didn't fly?"

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Oh, they shouldn't do such things. Are you sure this report is correct?

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: It gives details which couldn't be invented. Naturally I want to verify it and that's why I need you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You want me to go to Constantinople?

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: Yes... leaving immediately.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I appreciate the confidence you show in me, but I must ask you to entrust someone else with this mission. I should hate to interrupt my present work. I am positive that my survey is more important than finding out whether three of our comrades have been drinking some extra glasses of champagne.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: That is for me to decide, Comrade Yakushova.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I am sorry, I don't want to overstep my position -- but please... don't send me.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: How can I make myself clear... It is difficult to express but I'd rather not go to foreign countries any more. Please, Comrade... let me stay here... let me finish my work... I am in the rhythm of it now... I don't want to go away. I don't want to be sent into that foreign atmosphere again. It throws one out of gear.... Let me finish my work... I have concentrated everything in it... Please... don't make me go.

turns.speaker: RAZININ
turns.text: Please don't waste my time, Comrade. Do your duty. Good-by.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I will do my best.

turns.speaker: P√àRE MATHIEU
turns.text: This way, madame. Are you alone? By the window perhaps?  Or a nice little corner table?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: This will do.

turns.speaker: P√àRE MATHIEU
turns.text: I think this is the first time you have been to my little place. Your face is new to me. Now, what shall it be?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Raw carrots and beets.

turns.speaker: P√àRE MATHIEU
turns.text: Oh, madame! This is a restaurant, not a meadow.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Bring me something simple. I never think about food.

turns.speaker: P√àRE MATHIEU
turns.text: But, madame! If you don't think about food what do you think about?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: The future of the common people.

turns.speaker: P√àRE MATHIEU
turns.text: That also is a question of food, madame. I'll bring you a nice little lunch √† la P√®re Mathieu.
